roleset.name: to walk steadily
roleset.note: MARCH-V NOTES: Frames file for 'march' based on survey of sentences in the WSJ corpus. (from march.01-v predicate notes)
MARCH-N NOTES: Automatically created by Julia as an alias file for unification. (from march.01-n)

roles.note: Use argA for cases of an outside agent.

example.name: with direction
example.text: As the judge marched down the center aisle in his flowing black robe , he was heralded [*-128] by a trumpet fanfare .

example.name: with ArgA
example.text: Colleagues today recall with some humor how meetings would crawl into the early morning hours [*T*-1] as Mr. Dinkins would march his staff out of board meetings and into his private office [*-2]to discuss , en masse , certain controversial proposals .
example.arg: out of board meetings and into his private office
[*-2] to discuss , en masse , certain controversial proposals

example.name: intransitive
example.text: About 200,000 East Germans marched in Leipzig and thousands more staged protests in three other cities in a fresh challenge [*ICH*-1] to the Communist leadership [*]to introduce democratic freedoms .

roleset.name: to progress, advance
roleset.note: MARCH-V NOTES: Frames file for 'march' based on survey of sentences in the WSJ corpus. (from march.02-v predicate notes)

example.name: with direction
example.text: It was as short as 29 days at the start of this year , when rates were marching steadily upward [*T*-1] , and hit 42 days in August .
